qas.question: When Weld was re-elected governor, how much of the vote did he get?
What did Kerry and Weld agree to limit their campaign spending to?
Who broke the agreed-upon spending cap?

context: In 1996, Kerry faced a difficult re-election fight against Governor <a0_0>William Weld<a0_0/>, a popular Republican incumbent who had been re-elected in <a2_0>1994<a2_0/> with <a1_0>71%<a1_0/> of the vote. The race was covered nationwide as one of the most closely watched Senate races that year. Kerry and Weld held several debates and negotiated a campaign spending cap of <a3_0>$6.9 million<a3_0/> at Kerry's Beacon Hill townhouse. <a4_0>Both candidates<a4_0/> spent more than the cap, with each camp accusing the other of being first to break the agreement. During the campaign, Kerry spoke briefly at the 1996 Democratic National Convention. Kerry won re-election with 53 percent to Weld's 45 percent.
